question: Does it allow for expandable sd card??
answer: I just got my Samsung Galaxy S20 FE 5G and I can confirm without a doubt that there IS a slot for a microSD card! The people thumbing down that response are not paying attention. When you pull out the sim tray, there is a "platform" on the top labeled "sim card 1". You place your sim on that tray. UNDERNEATH is ANOTHER TRAY! You just turn the tray OVER and the other side says, "sim card 2/microSD card". You put another sim or your microSD card on THAT. Make sure you have the right size SD card, and/or you're putting it in correctly, for those complaining that it doesn't fit. You have to position it a certain way. Unfortunately, I'm using my phone to answer, so I can't show you in a video, but I was able to figure it out by myself. There ARE videos on YouTube, so just Google how to input your microSD for this device, if you want. (It should be common sense, especially with Google, and yet so many people never research anything prior to buying something, and then complain that they bought a device because it said it has a microSD card, and it doesn't). I just lined up the notches of the microSD card (the way the card is cut) with the notches of the tray, and voila! Now I'm off to buy a bigger microSD card (because I know I can!) ;) Good luck!

question: No headphone jack?  says it comes with akg headset.  is that wireless?
answer: The Samsung S21 FE continues the incredibly stupid design decision to remove a 3.5 mm headphone jack.  Unfortunately, most other competitive phones have done the same thing, so you've got to either go with a dongle (which risks breaking the USB-C port on the phone), or deal with all the hassles and low-fidelity of bluetooth buds.   Lord help you if one of those falls out of your ear while you're on the subway - there goes $100+.

question: Will this work on T Mobile 5 G?
answer: Yes - T-Mobile 5g is focused on fr1 also known as Sub-6 (ghz) - this means you can take advantage of their 600mhz paint the map 5g (which is the slowest but offers other actual usable benefits) but also supports mid-band, which t-mo has tons of spectrum in (PCS & AWS) there's also speculation that BRS acquired from sprint could be later added (higher frequency equals faster data rates at the cost of shrinking coverage)... This does not support mmwave (aka ultrawideband) offered by VZW - but, that's basically useless anyway as you can't leave the line of site to a tower and maintain a connection at mmwave 5g anyway and at present the only sub 6 band they are deploying is 3.5ghz which doesn't provide the same coverage as lower bands... ATT is playing both ends but tmo has the most functional 5g nationally as of the time of my writing this... Keep in mind, 5g sub 6 is not multi gig speeds like you might think... Faster than 4g lte but more efficient which means more capacity and more throughput per user... In urban areas, with adequate spectrum, I've seen speeds over 500mbps... Not sure about the references to a special firmware build needed for this phone - saw a comment here for the first time about that - but it doesn't make sense... You should notify t-mo of your upgrade, sometimes an updated sim is needed to take advantage of latest 5g 600mhz band they offer...

question: is this dual hybrid sim?

Google "S20 USA eSIM" for some pretty old forum threads complaining about that. Be aware of this and don't count on this feature.

question: How easy is it to open the case and insert an SD card?
answer: Insert a paper clip into the top of the phone and the tray ejects out of the phone.Top slot is the sim card, bottom slot is the micro SD card slot. This phone does not have a rear removable cover. (Can't open the case).

question: Does this work with mint mobile 5g?
answer: Right now there is no exact answer.  As I understand it Mint is an MVNO that uses T-Mobile towers where 5 g is available in specific limited areas.  T-Mobile is expanding its 5 g coverage but my information is that the OnePlus Nord 10 5g will work with the middle band.  5g has a low range and a high range band which are developmental in a word and it may be some time before there is a global availability.  There are problems with physical obstacles, etc. that affect reception that need to be overcome.  And there may not be an advantage over current LTE.  I would pay attention to how good the phone is currently and the value vs. the cost and I think this is a very good phone for the money.

question: Is this phone compatible with Visible Wireless?
answer: While the phone is compatible, when you go to their website and type in the IMEI number, it will tell you it will not work.It will work, I have one on Visible. I ran into this issue when Motorola first introduced the G power, I bought one from Motorola, when I typed in the IMEI on Visible, it said it would not work, so I bought the Pixel 4a.Now, a few months later, visible sells the G power, and when I type in my IMEI, it says, my phone will work! So I have a stand by spare!By the way, I took the sim card out of my Pixel and put it in the G fast, and it works fine. The problem is, if your IMEI says it won't work, they will not send you a sim card.

question: Can you buy minutes and use them until they're used up or do you need to pay monthly?
answer: You can buy minutes at any time if you buy a minutes plan. Unused minutes, data and texts roll over past the date. The date is also added on; for example, if you buy the $25 plan for 500 minutes, 500 texts and 500 mb data and sixty days to use them, if you don't use them in that sixty days, it rolls over until the sixty days expires. If you buy another $25 plan say, after 30 days on this plan, your 30 left over days plus 60 new days then bumps you out to 90 days, PLUS whatever minutes, data and texts you have left are added to the new purchase.  UNLESS, you buy an unlimited plan for $25 which is for one month only. Which you do not need to do. You can also pay the $125 for a whole year and get 2,000 minutes and 365 days to use them, plus GB of data and thousands of texts. Sometimes this plan goes on sale for $75 and it's a bargain.

question: Can i use this phone in the Philippines

Please check with your mobile service provider to see if your SIM is expected to operate. Please note that we never recommend buying a phone in one region for ongoing use in another as Motorola phones are only in warranty in the country/region in which they are intended for sale. - Mike
